subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order
msgSnippet: ... Yeah, it s surprising.  OTOH, it s surprising to Hindi-speakers that anglophones can t hear the three-way distinction between the syllables da , ta , and
messageBody:
Paige Gabhart scripsit:

> I agree with Moira. I use all three sounds: Awl, Ah and On. In fact,
> I really don't understand what some people mean when they say they can't
> hear the difference between Awl and On. It strikes me in a similar way
> as if they said they can't distinguish between blue and green.

Yeah, it's surprising. OTOH, it's surprising to Hindi-speakers that
anglophones can't hear the three-way distinction between the syllables
"da", "ta", and "tha". (Try it with someone local to you, if you can.)
The first two sound pretty much alike to us, corresponding to our "da",
whereas the last one sounds like our "ta".

> I have thought that those who say they can't hear the difference
> actually just means they don't use the Awl sound, i.e. they pronounce
> words such as "all" with the On sound.

No, really. I for example don't use On, and split the
On words between Ah (the LOT lexical set) and Awe (the
CLOTH lexical set).

> I expect that they can hear the difference if they listen closely to
> someone pronouncing Awl versus On even if it is not a distinction they
> make in their own speech.

Not easily, believe me.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
Female celebrity stalker, on a hot morning in Cairo:
"Imagine, Colonel Lawrence, ninety-two already!"
El Auruns's reply: "Many happy returns of the day!"
